subtitle: chapter 37 I go to America America
surely these people are Americans this
was my thought as a panoramic vision of
the Western faces passed before my
inward view immersed in meditation I was
sitting behind some dusty boxes in the
storm of the Ranchi school a private
spot was difficult to find during those
busy years with the youngsters
the vision continued and a vast
multitude gazing to be intently swept
actor like across the stage of
consciousness the store room door opened
as usual one of the young lads had
discovered my hiding place
come here boom all I cried gaily I have
news for you the Lord is calling me to
America to America the boy echoed my
words in a tone that implied that I had
said to the moon yes I'm going forth to
discover America like Columbus he
thought he had found India surely there
is a karmic link between these two lands
bimmel scampered away soon the whole
school was informed by the two-legged
newspaper I summon the bewildered
faculty and gave the school and his
charge I know you'll keep Laurie
Mosher's yoga ideals of Education ever
to the fore I said I shall write you
frequently God willing someday I shall
be back tears stood in my eyes like cast
the last look at the little boys in the
sunny acres of Ranchi a definite epoch
in my life had now closed
I knew henceforth I would dwell in Far
Lands i entrained for Calcutta a few
hours after my vision the following day
I received an invitation to serve as a
delegate from India to an International
Congress of religious liberals in
America it was to convene that year in
Boston under the auspices of the
American Unitarian Association my head
in a whirl I sought out Sri Yukteswar
and Serampore
guru J have just been invited to address
a religious Congress in America shall I
go all doors are open for you master
replied simply it is now or never
but sir I said in dismay what do I know
about public speaking seldom have I
given a lecture and never
in English English or no English your
words on yoga shall be heard in the West
I laughed well dear guru Jane I hardly
think the Americans will learn Bengali
please bless me with a push over the
hurdles of the English language when I
broke the news of my plans to father he
was utterly taken aback to him America
seemed incredibly remote he feared that
he might never see me again how can you
go he asked sternly who will finance you
as he had affectionately borne the
expense of my education whole life he
doubtless hoped this question would
bring my project to an embarrassing halt
the Lord will surely finance me as I
made this reply I thought of a similar
one I had given long ago to my brother
anata in agra without very much guile I
added father perhaps God will put it
into your mind to help me
no never he glanced at me piteously I
was astounded that for when father
handed me the following day a check made
out for a large amount I give you this
money said not in my capacity as a
father but as a faithful disciple of
larry masha go then to that far western
land spread there the creed 'less
teachings of kriya yoga i was immensely
touched the selfless spirit and which
father had been able to quickly put
aside his personal desires the just
realisation had come to him during the
preceding night that no ordinary desire
for foreign travel was motivating my
voyage perhaps we shall not meet again
in this life father who was 67 at the
time spoke sadly an intuitive conviction
prompted me to reply surely the Lord
will bring us together once more as I
went about my preparations to leave
Master in my native land for an unknown
Shore of America I experienced not a
little trepidation I had heard many
stories about the materialistic Western
atmosphere one very different from the
spiritual background of India pervaded
with the centered aura of saints an
oriental teacher who will dare the
western air as I thought must be hard a
beyond the trials of the Himalayan cold
one early morning they begin to pray
with
an atom and determination to continue to
even die praying until I heard the voice
of God I wanted his blessing and
assurance that I would not lose myself
in the fogs of modern utilitarianism my
heart was set to go to America but even
more strongly was it resolved to hear
the solace of divine permission I prayed
and prayed muffling my sobs no answer
came my silent petition increased in
excruciating crescendo until at noon I
had reached a Zenith my brain could no
longer withstand the pressure my Agony's
if I cried once more with increased
depth of my inner passion
I felt as all my brain would split at
that moment there came a knock outside
the vestibule adjoining the GUP highroad
room in which I was sitting opening the
door I saw a young man in a scanty garb
of a renunciate he came in closed the
door behind me and refusing my request
to sit down indicated with a gesture
that he wished to talk to me with
something
he must be Babaji I thought days because
the man before me had the features of a
young girl Airy Masha
he answered my thought yes I am babaji
he spoke melodiously in Hindi our
Heavenly Father has heard your prayer he
commands me to tell you follow the be
health of your guru and go to America
fear not you will be protected
after a vibrant pause Babaji addressed
me again you are the one I have chosen
to spread the message of Kriya yoga in
the West long ago I met your guru yoga
Schwar at kumbhamela I told him I would
send you to him for training I was
speechless choked with devotional
artists present and deeply touched to
hear from his own lips that he had
guided me to Sri Yukteswar
I lay prostrate before the deathless
guru he graciously lifted me from the
floor
tell me many things about my life he
then gave me some personal instructions
and uttered a few secret prophecies
Kriya yoga the scientific technique of
God realization he finally said with
solemnity will ultimately spread in all
lands and
harmonizing the nation through man's
personal transcendental perception of
the infinite father with a gaze of
majestic power the master electrified me
by a glimpse of his cosmic consciousness
in a short while he started toward the
door do not try to follow me he said you
will not be able to do so please Babaji
don't go away I cried repeatedly take me
with you
looking back he replied not now some
other time overcome by emotion I
disregard his warning as I tried to
pursue him I discovered that my feet
were firmly rooted to the floor from the
door Babaji gave me a last affection
glance he raised his hand by way of
benediction and walked away my eyes
fixed on him longingly after a few
minutes my feet were free i sat down and
went into deep meditation on Cesis lee
thanking God not only for answering my
prayer but for blessing me by meeting
with Babaji my whole body seemed
sanctified to the touch of the ancient
every youthful master long had it been
my burning desire to behold him until
now I never recounted to anyone the
story of my meeting with Babaji holding
it as the most sacred of my human
experience I have hidden it in my heart
but the thought occurred to me that
readers of this autobiography may be
more inclined to believe in the reality
the secluded Babaji of this world
interest if I relate that I saw him with
my own eyes I have helped an artist to
draw a picture of the great yogi
trenched of modern India it appears in
his book the eve of my departure for the
united states found me in Sri Yukteswar
holy presence forget you were born a
Hindu and don't be an American take the
best of them both masters said in his
calm way of wisdom be your true self a
child of God
seek and incorporate into your being the
best qualities of all your brothers
scattered over the earth and various
races then he blessed me all those who
come to you with faith seeking God will
be helped as you look at them the spear
actual current emanating from your eyes
will enter into their brains and change
their material habits making them more
God conscious he went on your lot of
attract sincere souls very good
everywhere you go even in the wilderness
you will find friends both of his
blessings have been amply demonstrated I
came alone to America into a wilderness
without a single friend but there I
found thousands ready to receive the
time-tested soul teaching I left India
in August 1920 on the city of Sparta the
first passenger boat sailing for America
after the close of World War one I had
been able to book passage only after the
removal in ways fairly miraculous of
many red tape difficulties concerned
with the granting of my passport during
the two months voyage a fellow passenger
found out that I was an Indian delegate
to the Boston Congress Swami Yogananda
he said with the first of many quaint
pronunciations by which I was later to
hear my name spoken by the Americans
please favor on the passengers of the
lecture next Thursday night I think we
would all benefit by the talk on the
Battle of life and how to fight it alas
I had to fight the battle of my own life
I discovered on Wednesday desperately
trying to organize my ideas into a
lecture in English I finally abandon all
preparations my thoughts like a wild
colt ina saddle refused any cooperation
with the laws of English grammar fully
trusting and masters past assurance
however I appeared before my Thursday
audience in the saloon of a steamer no
eloquence rose to my lips speechlessly I
stood before the assemblage after an
endurance contest lasting ten minutes
the audience realized my predicament and
began to laugh I stood on the dies
before one of my classes in America this
class of a thousand yoga students was
held in Washington DC the situation was
not funny to me at the moment
indignantly I sent a silent prayer to
master you can speak his voice sounded
instantly within my conscious
my thoughts fell at once into a friendly
relation of the English language 45
minutes later the audience was still
attentive the talk won me a number of
impatience to lecture later before
various groups in America I never could
remember afterward a ward that I had
spoken by discrete inquiry I learned
from a number of passengers you gave an
inspiring lecture and stirring and
cracked English at this delightful news
I humbly thank my guru for his timely
help realizing a new that he was ever
with me setting and all not all barriers
of time and space once in a while during
the remainder of the ocean trip I
experienced a few apprehensive twinges
about the coming English lecturer deal
at the Boston Congress Lord I prayed
please let my inspiration be thyself and
not again the laughter bombs of the
audience the city of Sparta docked in
Boston in late September on the 6th of
October I addressed the Congress with my
maiden speech in America it was well
received I signed relief the magnanimous
Secretary of the American Unitarian
Association wrote the following comment
in a published account of the Congress
proceeding Swami Yogananda delegate from
the Brahma Chaya ashram of Ranchi India
brought the greetings of his association
of the Congress in fluent English and a
forcible delivery he gave an address of
a philosophical character on the science
of religion which has been printed in
pamphlet form for a wider distribution
religion he maintained is universal and
it is one we cannot possibly
universalize particular customs and
convictions but the common element in
religion can be universalized
and we can ask all alike to follow no
bed due to father's generous check I was
able to remain in America after the
Congress was over for happy years were
spent in humble circumstances in Boston
I gave public lectures taught classes
and wrote a book on poems song to the
soul with a preface by dr. Frederick B
Robinson president of the College of the
city of New York
starting a transcontinental tour in the
summer of 1924 I spoke before thousands
in the principal cities ending my
Western trip with a vacation the
beautiful Alaskan north with the help of
a large hearted students by the end of
1925 and established American
headquarters on the Mount Washington
estates in Los Angeles the building is
the one I had seen years before in my
vision at Kashmir I hasten to send Sri
Yukteswar pictures of these distant
American activities he replied with a
postcard in Bengali which I here
translate August 11th 1920 sick child of
my heart or Yogananda seen the folders
of your school and students what joy
comes in my life I cannot express in
words I melted in joy to see your yoga
students on different cities be holding
your methods and chant affirmations
healing vibration and divine healing
prayers I cannot refrain from thanking
you from my heart seeing the gate the
Windley and hilly way upward and the
beautiful scenery spread out beneath the
Mount Washington estate I yearn to
behold it all with my own eyes
everything here is going well through
the grace of God may you ever be in
bliss Sri Yukteswar Giri years sped by I
lectured in every part of my new land
and addressed hundreds of clubs colleges
churches and groups of every
denomination tens of thousands of
Americans received yoga initiation to
them all I dedicate a new book of prayer
thoughts in 1929 whispers from eternity
with a preface by Amelie T Gallagher C I
give here from the book a poem entitled
God God God composed one night as I
stood on the lecture platform from the
depth of slumber as I ascend the spiral
stairway of wakefulness I whisper God
God God thou art the food and when I
break my fast o nightly separation from
thee I taste thee and mentally say God
God God no matter where I go the
spotlight of my mom
and ever keeps turning on thee and then
the battle din of activity my southern
war cry as ever God God God
when boisterous storms of trial shriek
and when worries howl at me I drown
their clamor loudly Clanton God God God
when my mind weaves dreams with threads
of memories then on that magic cloth I
find embossed God God God every night in
time of deep asleep my peace dreams and
calls joy joy joy and my joy comes
singing evermore God God God in waking
eating working dreaming sleeping serving
meditating chanting divinely loving my
soul constantly hums unheard by any God
God God sometimes used me on the first
of the month when the bills rolled in
for upkeep of the Mount Washington and
other self-realization fellowship
centers I thought longingly of the
simple piece of India but daily I saw
widening understanding between West and
East my soul rejoiced I have found the
great heart of America expressed in the
wondrous lines by Emma Lazarus carved on
the base of the Statue of Liberty the
mother of X Isles from her beacon hand
glows worldwide welcomed her mild eyes
command the air bridged Harbor the Twin
Cities frame keep ancient lands your
storied pomp cries she with silent lips
give me your tired your poor your
huddled masses yearning to breathe free
the wretched refuse of your teeming
Shore send these the homeless
tempest-tossed to me I lift my lamp
beside the Golden Door end of chapter
